titlestmt.titleproper: Register to The Richard Donovan Papers
titlestmt.author: Compiled by Cindy Clark

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday April 23, 2019 at 00:32

did.abstract: Music, correspondence and other papers, photographs, and additional materials by and about the American composer, conductor, and educator Richard Donovan (1891-1970)

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The Papers are open to researchers by appointment. There are no restricted materials in the collection. Please contact the Special Collections staff to schedule an appointment.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: The Richard Donovan Papers were established in the Music Library of Yale University by Richard Donovan, Jr. and David Donovan in 1972.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Richard Donovan Papers are the physical property of the Irving S. Gilmore Music Library of Yale University. Copyrights belong to the composers and authors, or their legal heirs and assigns.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: MSS 7, The Richard Donovan Papers in the Irving S. Gilmore Music Library of Yale University.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: In 8 series as follows: I. Correspondence. II. Photographs. III. Programs. IV. Newspaper Clippings. V. Classroom Materials. VI. Personal Effects. VII. Donovan's Works. VIII. Works of Other Composers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Richard Donovan Papers contain material from Donovan's long and active life as a composer, teacher, conductor, and important musical force in the New Haven area. They include approximately 300 personal letters; correspondence concerning the publication of his works; material dealing with the American Composers Alliance and the Yaddo festivals; photographs (chiefly of Donovan); concert programs; newspaper clippings, ranging from reviews of his works to articles on 20th-century composers and book reviews; many classroom notebooks from his years as a professor at the Yale School of Music; sketches, holographs, transparencies, photocopies and published versions of his musical works; and musical works of other contemporary composers.

Donovan's works cover a wide variety of genres. In the field of vocal music he wrote several songs for solo voice, and works for chorus with orchestral accompaniment as well as many choral arrangements, anthems, and secular part-songs. He favored the oboe as a solo instrument for his chamber music, but also composed two piano trios, a quartet for woodwinds, and several works for unusual combinations such as his Soundings, for trumpet, bassoon, and percussion. His keyboard works include two suites for piano, and three pieces for organ (Antiphon and Chorale being the best known). American folk tunes figure in many of Donovan's compositions, especially in his orchestral music. New England Chronicle and Passacaglia on Vermont Folk Tunes are to be noted here. Other orchestral works include a symphony, two symphonic poems, and overtures. Several of Donovan's pieces have been recorded, and many were performed regularly during his lifetime both in America and abroad. The Papers also contain a small sampling (in holograph, photoduplicated and printed form) of works by other 20th-century composers. Everett Helm, Paul Hindemith, Horatio Parker, Quincy Porter, and Halsey Stevens number among those represented.

Within the correspondence collection are letters from such contemporary composers as Aaron Copland, Peggy Glanville-Hicks, Howard Hanson, Ernst Krenek, Otto Luening, Walter Piston, Quincy Porter, Mel Powell, Carl Ruggles, Gunther Schuller, Halsey Stevens, Randall Thompson and Virgil Thomson. A small collection of correspondence between Donovan and Beckett Gibbs, found within the classroom materials, points out Donovan's interest in the performance of plainsong. Father Gibbs specialized in that field, and Donovan wrote him numerous letters asking for detailed information.

The Donovan Papers would be of greatest interest to those doing research on musical events in New Haven and New York between 1920 and 1969; to those seeking information on the development and activities of the Yaddo festivals and the American Composers Alliance; to those following the growth and changes in the Yale School of Music; and certainly to those studying any aspect of 20th-century music.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Richard Frank Donovan was born in New Haven, Connecticut on November 29, 1891. He attended the Yale School of Music and the Institute of Musical Art, receiving his bachelor's degree from the latter in 1922. He also taught at the Institute (later known as the Juilliard School) for several years. After teaching, conducting, and playing the organ in New York, Donovan became the director of music at the Taft School in Watertown, Connecticut in 1920. Three years later he joined the music faculty at Smith College, and in 1928 he returned to the Yale School of Music, first as an instructor, and later (1947) as Battell Professor of the Theory of Music; he also served as Acting Dean in 1940-1941.

In addition to teaching, Donovan served in several other musical capacities in New Haven. He conducted the Bach Cantata Club from 1933 until 1944, worked with the New Haven Symphony Orchestra as associate conductor from 1936 until 1951, and was organist and choirmaster of Christ Church from 1928 until 1966. Donovan was also affiliated with the Pan American Association of Composers and Yaddo (for which he served as a director of the corporation). He served on the Board of Governors of the American Composers Alliance, and was a member of the Executive Board of New Music publications.
Richard Donovan died on August 22, 1970 in Middletown, Connecticut.

odd.head: General
odd.p: Correspondence is organized in the following categories:

A. Letters to Richard Donovan, arranged in alphabetical order by the last name of the sender. Within each name, the letters are then placed in chronological order. Unidentified material is grouped together at the end of the alphabet, followed by miscellaneous letters from and to people other than Donovan.

B. Letters.from Donovan, arranged in alphabetical order by the last name of recipient. Again, within each name the letters are organized chronologically. Recommendations and unidentified letters are filed at the end.

C. Concerning publication: subdivided into 3 categories--legal, letters between Donovan and the various publishing houses, and miscellaneous correspondence. Within these categories the letters are arranged alphabetically and/or chronologically.
The final divisions (D E F G) concern American Composers Alliance, Yaddo festivals, and the Yale School of Music, and the New Haven Symphony Orchestra respectively.

odd.head: General
odd.p: Photographs are arranged as follows: Donovan alone, Donovan family group pictures including Donovan, other people, with unidentified pictures coming at the end. These photos consist of individuals such as Elizabeth Ames (director of Yaddo festivals), Max Polikoff, Henry Cowell, and includes a signed postcard photo of Charles Widor.

did.unittitle: Grace Donovan and son; son alone
Donovan conducting New Haven Symphony and School of Music group
Burton, Margaret Crofts, Max Pollikoff, Hinrichsen, Donovan
Donovan, Henry Gowell, Elizabeth Ames, Avery Claflin
St. Peters Cathedral in Rome, inside

odd.head: General
odd.p: This collection of programs is divided into 3 main categories: Those on which Donovan's works were performed, those for which Donovan served as conductor or performer, those which Donovan attended.
Also included are programs on which Grace Donovan (Mrs.) sang, and New Haven Symphony programs during the time Donovan was associate conductor but for which he did not conduct.

odd.head: General
odd.p: Donovan conductor but not of these programs.

odd.head: General
odd.p: The clippings found in this section deal with several areas:
Reviews of Donovan's works (arranged alphabetically by the name of the work).
Articles which Donovan collected concerning composers (Bach-Wagner) arranged alphabetically.
Articles which Donovan collected covering periods of music.
Miscellaneous articles (on instruments, book reviews, etc.)

did.unittitle: Miscellaneous and recommendations to the library

odd.head: General
odd.p: Notebooks containing Donovan's classroom materials (lecture notes, exams, articles, etc.) comprise this section. Included in the materials for his Gregorian Chant courses are a group of letters to and from Beckett Gibbs concerning the performance practices of plainsong. Student papers are also found here.

odd.head: General
odd.p: Vaughan Williams Symphony in F minor.

did.unittitle: Lectures by Donovan on various subjects

odd.head: General
odd.p: As can be seen from the register, this is a group of very miscellaneous things found in the collection, and includes biographical material, pocket reminders, check registers, and Donovan's notebooks concerning Europe.

did.unittitle: Biographical material written by Donovan for publications; awards
Lists of Donovan's works, background information and program notes for various works, etc.

odd.head: General
odd.p: Donovan's musical works have been divided into 3 categories according to size:
A. Octavo editions (27 cm.) Arranged alphabetically.
C. Oversize works (larger than 37 cm.) Arranged alphabetically.
Housed with the octavo editions are song texts Donovan collected but never used, and housed with the oversize works are unidentified sketches of music in Donovan's hand.
To help the user, a categorical listing of Donovan's works can be found in the Index section.

odd.head: General
odd.p: Herein can be found the manuscript and photocopy works of such composers as Violet Archer, Everett Helm, Paul Hindemith, Frank Lewin, Quincy Porter, Halsey Stevens and Yehudi Wyner. These are arranged alphabetically by last name of composer. Mimeograph works are mostly student projects.
